content.intro:
A city both creative and dynamic, Porto unveils its charms and heritage along the Douro River. With displays of Romanesque and Baroque architectures, the city that was awarded best European destination on multiple occasions will fulfil your cravings for culture, history and blazing colours.

There is an old saying in town: "Lisbon plays while Porto works". It has lost its meaning in our day and age, but as the second largest city in Portugal, Porto still owes its development to the trade of textile, cork and of course Porto wine.
For the last few years, Porto has experienced unprecedented cultural, artistic and touristic growth. With some 200,000 inhabitants, it has been elected best European destination a number of times . This dynamic exhilaration is particularly palpable in the historical centre, especially on the Rua Galeria de Paris, the trendiest district. Buildings long left in a state of neglect are now being restored and turned into sumptuous hotels travellers are fond of. In the city's newest districts, all around the old town, you'll you will discover the Casa da Música, a new-fangled venue designed by Dutch urban planner Rem Koolhaas. Also of major interest is the Contemporary Art Museum (Fundação de Serralves), conceived by celebrated local boy and contemporary architect Álvaro Siza.
Omnipresent azulejos on the façades of historical buildings are one of the reminders that the Cidade Invicta (the 'undefeated city') never forgot about culture and traditions. You will discover the story behind the famous drink conceived in the Douro valley, sheltered by the Marão mountains, in the town of Vila Nova de Gaia on the other side of the river - heartland of the greatest wine producers. Several sun-filled grape varieties are used to produce different kinds of Porto wines: White, Ruby, Tawny, Late Bottle Vintage (LBV) and Vintage. Do not leave town before trying these typical nectars… as long as you drink in moderation, of course. Here, port wine and food pairing is essential and makes for a terrific way of trying out local specialities.

content.title: Get your fill of culture

introduction.small: Look out, for you are about to enter a place filled with history! Founded in 1833, the Museu Nacional do Soares dos Reis was Portugal's very first public art museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Get your fill of culture

paragraphs.text:
Regent Dom Pedro IV wished to preserve and promote the monasteries' artistic properties and heritage for cultural and educational purposes, so he set up a museum in Porto for their canvases and engravings. From 1940 onwards, Museu Nacional do Soares dos Reis took up room in the Palácio dos Carrancas Neoclassical building. Works across the ages by Silva Porto, Gaspar Vaz and Henrique Pousão are on display in the permanent collections of Portuguese painting, and you will also find foreign paintings by Francis Clouet and Pierre-Antoine Quillard.
Other highlights include pieces of jewellery, ancient European and Eastern ceramics, Indian-Portuguese furniture and religious art. Wander through the sculptures of famous artist António Soares dos Reis, around the fountain in the Palace gardens, or among the shelving of a Hogwarts-like library.

Museu Nacional Soares dos Reis
Palácio dos Carrancas
Rua Dom Manuel II 44
4050-342 Porto

+351 22 339 3770

www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt/en-GB/default.aspx

content.title: A stay fit for a king at Pousada Mosteiro Guimarães

introduction.small: Practically a museum in its own right, this fascinating inn (pousada) is located in a former monastery (mosteiro) and overlooks the medieval town of Guimarães.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A stay fit for a king at Pousada Mosteiro Guimarães

paragraphs.text:
The city of Guimarães has been a UNESCO world heritage site since 2002. Back in the 12th century, it was Portugal's first capital city. The first King of Portugal Afonso Henriques strengthened his rule by giving land to the Church and founding many convents, including the Augustin Convent. The former cloisters and cells have been turned into a superb museum hotel, or hotel museum, depending on how you want to see it. It has been redone in 1985 by famous architect Fernando Luís Cardoso de Meneses de Tavares e Távora, also known as "Fernando Távora" - who subsequently redeveloped the city centre. In addition to the hotel's comfortable hotel rooms, all of which are fit for a king, there is also a fascinating bar located in what used to be the monastery's kitchen – you will never get tired of looking at it. And neither will you of its chapter house, deep couches facing the huge fireplace, or terrace overlooking the city and gardens with their olive groves and orchard spread out over twenty-five acres.

Hotel Pousada Mosteiro Guimarães
Largo Domingos Leite de Castro
Lugar da Costa
4810-011 Guimarães

+351 25 351 1249

https://www.pousadas.pt/uk/hotel/pousada-guimaraes

Rooms: from 123 EUR

content.title: Atrevo, for the love of fine food

introduction.small: In Portuguese, atrevo means “to dare”: and staking everything on locally-sourced food, sustainability and sharing is daring indeed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Atrevo, for the love of fine food

paragraphs.text:
After a visit to the Igreja de Santo Ildefonso - a stunning 18th-century church covered in 11,000 azulejos - just 600m along the road you will find yet another of Porto's wonders, this time focused on fine dining.

It sits on a quiet cobbled street in the Bonfim district, away from the hustle and bustle of the traditional tourist trails. Although only recently established, it is here that young chef Tânia Durão has begun sharing her passion for family food and seasonal produce through a daringly modern and innovative menu.

Speak to Tânia, and she is quick to sing the praises of her regular suppliers - people like José, whose produce is so delicious it could have come out of your grandmother's garden.

At Atrevo, each set menu consists of five or eight ‘moments', each of which showcases a key ingredient in a modern and inventive way. You may, for example, get to sample senhorita Tânia's take on flaky brioche, or scorpion fish with lemon verbena. If you see it on the menu, do not miss the chance to try one of her favourite creations: mushrooms with truffle and egg yolk! One last tip is to make sure to book your table in advance - this spot is exceedingly popular with locals.

Atrevo Restaurante
Rua Morgado de Mateus 49
4000-333 Porto

+351 96 822 6456

https://www.atrevo.pt

Menu: around 45 EUR

content.title: Rota Do Chá, on the tea trail

introduction.small: One of its kind in Porto, the Rota Do Chá tea salon mixes styles and tea varieties, from India to Japan by way of Morocco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rota Do Chá, on the tea trail

paragraphs.text:
Giving onto Miguel Bombarda street, an arty hotspot that has to be seen, a discreet door feels like entering an apartment block. Except that Rota Do Chá awaits at the end of a long corridor. This atypical tea salon set up in a living room would have fitted a Victorian house at the time of the Colonial British Indies: period chairs, framed pictures on the walls displaying maps of the Empire as well as family photos, and of course tea on all tables. The establishment therefore pays tribute to Portugal's particular history with the drink, as the State largely contributed to its spreading through Europe during the 16th century. Explore the "tea trail", roam the living room and sit in front of the statue of Buddha, in a Zen patio bearing both Moroccan and Japanese influences. Here, you are in no rush. Take your time, find yourself, relax and calmly enjoy this suspended moment. Furthermore, with 300 tea references on the menu, choosing might take some time!

Rota Do Chá
Rua Miguel Bombarda 457
4050-382 Porto

+351 22 013 6726

https://www.facebook.com/RotaDoCha/

Menu: drinks from 1 EUR

content.title: Vegan Portuguese specialities at Em Carne Viva

introduction.small: Forget about meat and fish, everywhere to be found in Portuguese cuisine. At Em Carne Viva, regional gastronomy is revived with vegan cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vegan Portuguese specialities at Em Carne Viva

paragraphs.text:
Vegan, vegetarian, or simply curious about new plant-based food trends? Then head to Em Carne Viva, a corner restaurant in the Boavista neighbourhood that produces endless vegan variations of Portuguese cuisine with the same great flavours as before.

Enter this small and narrow house, climb up the wooden staircase and gaze at the mouldings around you. Upstairs, waxed wooden floors and a major marble fireplace adorn the living room-turned dining hall. Under a glass chandelier, food lovers sit comfortably on wood and burgundy velvet chairs. On sunny days, ask for a table in the garden located in the back of the restaurant, for a special intimate moment filled with romanticism. Alternately, if the weather grows colder, a conservatory will welcome you.

The place speaks for itself: here, you will only be served gastronomic-level dishes. The menu draws direct inspiration from Porto's traditional cooking, with a touch of fun (Em Carne Viva means "raw meat"). For instance, if you order a francesinha, the beef steak will be replaced by a surprising red bean one. The tofu is cooked a lagareiro with olive oil and garlic, while vegan meatballs reproduce the flavours of the alheira Portuguese sausage. At Em Carne Viva, each speciality gets the vegan treatment, and the bet is to always retain their original essence.

Em Carne Viva
Avenida da Boavista 868
4100-112 Porto

+351 93 235 2722

www.emcarneviva.pt/home/?lang=en

Menu: around 17 EUR

content.title: Cantina 32, trendy stop on Rua das Flores

introduction.small: Located along this historical alley in Porto, in a former perfume factory, Cantina 32's trendy setting and cuisine are all the rage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cantina 32, trendy stop on Rua das Flores

paragraphs.text:
If you happen to walk around Rua das Flores, Porto's colourful historical alley, you have to stop by Cantina 32. The front of this former perfume factory is unmissable, with its green gate and blue mosaic tiles on the facade. Inside, you will notice that the industrial look, grey walls and wooden structure have all been retained. A few vintage elements, like an old typewriter here, or an old bike hanging there, add an extra something to the décor. Just like a canteen, you will sit at large shared tables. Feeling puckish or truly hungry? Want to share or eat it all? All choices will be met. Take a look at the menu of this trendy bistro, with blood sausage and apples, tuna steak with pineapple, sesame seeds, and coriander, or even a whole octopus. End the meal with an Oreo cheesecake displayed in a flowerpot topped with a sprout, like a blossoming seed. At night, the retro decoration and big Edison lightbulbs hanging around contribute to the warm feeling. You can stay and chat with friends for hours on.

Cantina 32
Rua das Flores 32
4050-262 Porto

+351 22 203 9069

https://www.cantina32.com/en/

Menu: around 13 EUR

content.title: Puro 4050, mozzarella in the spotlight

introduction.small: Porto's first mozzarella bar, Puro 4050 offers a wide range of the Italian cheese, in almost every dish.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Puro 4050, mozzarella in the spotlight

paragraphs.text:
In a trendy and welcoming atmosphere, Puro 4050 pays tribute to Italian trattorie, with small rustic wooden tables, china and paintings depicting Tuscan scenes. The smell of warm and crispy bread fills the air of this restaurant entirely devoted to mozzarella. The owner brought back various types of that cheese from his culinary pilgrimage to Italia. Mozzarella lovers will get to sample it plain, in bocconcini (small balls of fresh mozzarella) or affumicata (smoked). Discover the chef's original combinations settled in near an 18th-century-style bookshelf, at the huge table of the underground level for friends or family reunions, or simply on the outdoor terrace. Accompanied by vegetables and fruits (lollo red salad with Italian chicory and cherry tomatoes in pesto for instance), cold cuts (mortadella from Bologna, coppa, bresaola) or in pizza form like a focaccia, the Italian cheese will always find its way to your plate.

Puro 4050
Largo de São Domingos 84
4050-050 Porto

+351 22 201 1852 / +351 92 600 1556

https://www.facebook.com/Puro-4050-708473529255288/

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Mysteries and closeness at Pedro Limaõ

introduction.small: In the heart of the lively Bonfim neighbourhood, chef Pedro Limaõ launched his restaurant with closeness as the key word.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mysteries and closeness at Pedro Limaõ

paragraphs.text:
At first sight, Pedro Limaõ's dining room looks bewildering. Very informal and minimalist, it tremendously steps away from the arrangements usually found in the restaurant industry. Standing on the threshold, it will be hard to miss the tiny open kitchen, laid out like in an apartment. Serving 20 people only, the chef bets on a "non-restaurant" concept that favours closeness with patrons, treated like friends at a reunion dinner. The menu changes regularly, according to Pedro's mood, and offers a highly creative culinary experience. Playing the mystery card, it only shows the main ingredient used for each dish - the rest varies, depending on the seasons and the chef's whim. Choose the “tasting menu” for a culinary journey divided into several experimental stages. Otherwise, simply order the "potato", the "beef tongue" or the enigmatic "leave me alone" and surrender to the sweetest surprise…

Pedro Limaõ
Rua do Morgado de Mateus 51-53
4000-334 Porto

+351 96 645 4599

https://www.pedrolimao.com/en

Menu: around 47 EUR

content.title: Explore the world at the Natural History and Science Museum

introduction.small: After the renovation and fusion of two museums – Science on one side and Natural History on the other, discover how the world evolved through various angles of Porto's University.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the world at the Natural History and Science Museum

paragraphs.text:
In one of Porto's most touristic neighbourhoods, the University occupies historical buildings. The science department found its home in an old presbytery and now welcomes history and natural science enthusiasts. Four large collections, like geology and zoology, will take curious visitors for a journey across the globe. The palaeontology section in particular remains quite impressive among young and old alike, with fossils (animals and plants) and dinosaur bone reproductions. As for the archaeological and anthropological parts, dealing with the development of our societies, they tell of the major scientific missions carried out during the Portuguese colonial Empire. The large collections of African, Asian and Melanesian arts, as well as instruments and tools are all being shed a light on through original study documentation. Two short kilometres away, the Campo Alegre Botanical Garden is also well worth a visit. Once there, check out the playful sensory experiences: visitors of all ages will love them.

Natural History and Science Museum of the University of Porto

https://mhnc.up.pt

Porto Botanical Garden

content.title: Relaxing in the heart of Porto at Hotel Royal

introduction.small: Porto is the perfect city for lively nights out. It is also filled with sumptuous monuments, steeped in history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Relaxing in the heart of Porto at Hotel Royal

paragraphs.text:
Three minutes away from Praça da Batalha in Porto's historical centre, a cocooning atmosphere awaits you at Hotel Royal! Right from the lobby, clear stone walls, mouldings and stylish chandeliers will seduce you. In the 12 bedrooms, which all offer dazzling views over the Douro River, and may sometimes welcome up to five persons, expect modern design with white beds and furniture, mirrors and lovely flowerpots! If you are craving for more excursions, enjoy the hotel's advantageous location, situated right by the city centre, listed as UNESCO World Heritage. Only a few steps further south, discover the Muralha Fernandina or the magnificent Estátua de Vímara Peres. Take this opportunity to visit the Livraria Lello located nearby. Also known as the "Chardron bookshop", it sets up a very magical kind of atmosphere.

Hotel Royal
Rua Alexandre Herculano 239
4000-054 Porto

+351 22 205 6483

www.hotelroyal.pt

Rooms: from 59 EUR

content.title: White night in Porto

introduction.small: In the span of a few years, Porto has become THE place to party! Here are a few hot tips for a wild night out, Porto-style!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: White night in Porto

paragraphs.text:
Your evening should start at the Aduela Taberna-Bar. Order a strawberry sangria to pair with a few tapas, best enjoyed under the olive tree marking the street corner, in an artsy, bohemian, friendly and relaxed atmosphere. In case you feel peckish, indulge in a few typically Portuguese snacks. A little bit further, head to Gulden Draak Bierhuis to sip on a cocktail, a tripel or an abbey beer, comfortably seated on one of the sofas of this trendy spot. Check the time: the night is still young and you have no intention of going home, so there is no reason to panic. The Maus Hábitos is a mere ten minutes away by foot. Not content with being one of the coolest bars in Porto, this cultural centre also presents mind-blowing concerts every night. There, you will be able to release all your energy until the morning sunrise, a drink in hand - in moderation! - and electricity in the air!

content.title: Ode Porto Wine House, out of time

introduction.small: In the heart of Porto's historic district, the kitchens of the Ode Porto Wine House fume and perfume Douro's banks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ode Porto Wine House, out of time

paragraphs.text:
Exposed wooden beams, ochre stones walls and small slate tables are gathered in the warm atmosphere of the Ode Porto Wine House. Along the Douro River, the restaurant sells out every day despite its discretion. The watchword: freshness. The chef prepares his dishes using local products and organic ingredients from neighbouring farmers. A way for him to pay tribute to his grandmother's cooking, and to all people who actually take the time to fill their dishes with love.

Surrender and enjoy cod in chickpeas, a beefsteak with strawberry reduction, or the alheira, one of Portugal's specialities made from Iberian pork. A few delicious hours later, eat up your meat pie with mushrooms, served with a tasty Pinot noir. Book your table soon, the Ode Porto Wine House is looking forward to making you savour the purest flavours of an invincible city.

Ode Porto Wine House
Largo do Terreiro 7
4050-603 Porto

+351 91 320 0010

www.odeporto.com/en_GB/

Menu: about 48 EUR

content.title: The typical delights of the Cervejaria Brasão Aliados

introduction.small: Go for Porto's speciality in one of the city's best Francesinhas restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The typical delights of the Cervejaria Brasão Aliados

paragraphs.text:
Within its stone walls and rough lumber beams, iron-wrought coats of arms and marvellous tiling work on the floor, the Cervejaria Brasão Aliados fills plates and hearts with the most delicious generosity. Around the well-supplied central bar, small tables are gathered in an authentic Portuguese setting, perfect to focus on the real star here: the Francesinha. According to many regulars, this is one of the very best in town.
This typical Porto dish is almost as famous as the Douro. The story goes that a Portuguese man who had moved to France found the famous croque-monsieur so bland that he decided to adapt it. The famous Lusitanian used slices of white bread covered in cheese, with steak, cooked ham, pork sausage and bologna tucked in between… This creation is then grilled and topped in a house hot sauce. To be tasted ASAP!

Cervejaria Brasão Aliados
Rua de Ramalho Ortigão 28
Porto 4000-407

+351 93 415 8672

https://brasao.pt/en/aliados-en

Menu: around 16 EUR

content.title: Pestana Vintage Porto – Vintage charm facing the river

introduction.small: Comprising 18 connected and completely modernised 16th century buildings, this iconic hotel reveals the past history of Porto and offers views over the Douro River.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pestana Vintage Porto – Vintage charm facing the river

paragraphs.text:
From the comfort of your room, watch the boats slide back and forth on the Douro in historical Ribeira district. Note that the Pestana Vintage Porto is the only hotel in town to offer this stunning view. The hotel, among several historical colourful buildings - typical of Portuguese architecture - was inaugurated in the 2000s. It was renovated by Lisboan designer Cristina Matos and now has a "vintage" look.
Discover the hotel, building after building. Inside, all 103 rooms and suites are decorated in 1950s style. The decorator mixed antiques and custom-made furniture. The only room on the ground floor combines a gallery of portraits, design accessories, and cut stone walls, while other smaller rooms are cosy and charming.
Come for breakfast at the Rib Beef & Wine restaurant where you may also have lunch and dinner. And should you choose to go for a cruise down the Douro, the pier is right out front.

Pestana Vintage Porto
Praça da Ribeira 1
4050-513 Porto

+351 22 340 2300

https://www.pestanacollection.com/uk/hotel/pestana-porto

Rooms: from 150 EUR

content.title: The Minho region, stronghold of vinho verde

introduction.small: In Northern Portugal, the Minho region attracts wine lovers and nature-goers looking for unique cultural folklore.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Minho region, stronghold of vinho verde

paragraphs.text:
For centuries, pilgrims walking from the South of Portugal have had to cross the Minho region to reach Santiago de Compostela and they may have left some traces of wisdom through this wine region on their way. Forests and green valleys, covered with vineyards as far as the eye can see, melt with the sea on the western horizon line.
Inns, old manors and mansions each more beautiful than the last, as well as small churches hidden in the valleys all contribute to the genuine and natural charm of the province, which is easily accessible by car under one hour from Porto. The famous vinho verde is made on this rich soil. Take some time to taste – in moderation – this delicious dry and sparkling white wine. Here, the mood is constantly sunny, no matter the weather! The kind local vine growers will happily welcome and guide you. The region is renowned for its local craftsmanship, so do not hesitate and stop at the various shops that border the roadsides.

Posto de Turismo de Vieira do Minho
(Vieira do Minho Tourist Information Centre)

https://vieiraminhoturismo.com

content.title: Porto, an anomaly of time and beauty

introduction.small: Visiting Porto is akin to a journey through time, with filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira's voice over to guide you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Porto, an anomaly of time and beauty

paragraphs.text:
Porto is not like any other European city. It does not hold fake-looking districts, with office buildings drained of all inhabitants. Real life is still happening, and the nice decorations on the façades of buildings bear witness to ongoing activity. Welcome to the Cidade Invicta (the "Undefeated City"), hotspot of trade and culture at the mouth of the Douro River. Walk around the Avenida dos Aliados and learn about the history of the Porto-São Bento station by studying its walls covered in azulejos - the famous earthenware that adorns buildings all over Portugal. Gather your thoughts in the dark Sé do Porto fortress cathedral, built in the 12th century. Or rejoice in the luxury of the 14th-century São Francisco church. You may also want to enjoy the vista onto the Douro and wine cellars from Torre dos Clérigos (built in the 18th century), and gaze upon the Dom Luís I bridge from the Ribeira riverbank. And if you are a Harry Potter enthusiast, head over to the Livrario Lello, one of the most beautiful bookshops in the world...

content.title: The Wine House Hotel, an ideal stay

introduction.small: Originality, modernity, gastronomy and oenology; experience them all courtesy of The Wine House Hotel at Quinta da Pacheca.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Wine House Hotel, an ideal stay

paragraphs.text:
The Wine House Hotel sits at the heart of the renowned Quinta da Pacheca estate, which dates all the way back to the 16th century. For a “classic” stay, opt for one of the 15 luxury rooms, found in a typical 18th-century house that has been renovated based on the purest tradition. Or, if adventure and picture-postcard views are more your thing, you will be sorely tempted by one of the estate's 10 “Wine Barrel Houses”: giant wine casks where you will find everything you need to enjoy a romantic night away (or maybe even longer!), surrounded by the beauty of the vineyards. A stay here is a special chance to get back to nature, as well as up close and personal with the day-to-day of viticulture in the Douro region. No matter which accommodation you choose, there are all sorts of activities to enjoy during a stay here at Quinta da Pacheca: from wine tasting to oenology classes, guided tours of the estate, an outdoor swimming pool, and of course dinner overlooking the bluish reflections of the Douro River.
Surrounded by a superb park and several acres of vine, la Quinta da Pacheca can also accommodate special events: from a simple business meeting to a wedding planning, the hotel will eagerly address your every need, both in terms of aesthetics and cuisine. Chef Carlo Pires will make sure to turn your stay into a true culinary adventure with generous Portuguese cooking, serving goose-neck barnacles, beer stuffed crab or sea bass baked in salt crust.

Pacheca - The Wine House Hotel
Rua do Relógio do Sol 261
Cambres

+351 25 433 1229

https://quintadapacheca.com/

Rooms: from 122 EUR

content.title: The Mercador Café, for an energy boost!

introduction.small: In the downtown neighbourhood of la Ribeira, the Mercado Café turns breakfasts and brunches into events, for the greatest pleasure of locals and travellers alike.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Mercador Café, for an energy boost!

paragraphs.text:
Upon seeing the old-fashioned storefront, you would assume the Mercador Café has been here for a hundred years. The truth is, the café is actually among the newcomers in Old Porto. The window display, the cosy feel inside, and the pretty little terrace rouse the passersby' curiosity.
Inside, a nice wooden bar lines the space, Art Deco light fixtures project delicate lighting onto the tables and an impressive display of tempting delights stands by the door. Fresh juice in carafes and steaming hot cups of coffee are served to clients who have come for a relaxing break before getting on with their day. You too can come devour the best breakfast in town. White omelettes or Popeye eggs (with spinach), homemade Granola, waffles beefed up with peanut butter and banana, or toasts with smoked salmon await. You will stock up on energy to enthusiastically walk the streets of Porto.

content.title: Stock Exchange Palace, a feast for the eyes

introduction.small: Built in 1834, the Palácio da Bolsa (Stock Exchange Palace) remains one of the must-go-to monuments of your stay in Porto.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stock Exchange Palace, a feast for the eyes

paragraphs.text:
The Neoclassical façade is a promise in itself, but the wondrous galleries you will discover inside the building deliver even more. Far from a classical construct, the palace exudes surprising exoticism. One must remember that World fairs used to set the example everywhere in Europe in the early 19th century (the opening took place in London in 1851). With that notion in mind, the building was designed to really blow visitors away.
Do not miss the most famous room of the whole palace, the immense ball room called Salão Árabe (Arab Room). Built in stucco made of exotic woods coming from Portuguese colonies, the Moorish decor displays 40 pounds of gold finish. According to experts, it is a possible imitation of Granada's Alhambra. Make a final stop in the large dining room: sheltered by a huge skylight, it is decorated with the coats of arms of every country which traded with Portugal at the time.

Palácio da Bolsa

+351 22 339 9000

https://palaciodabolsa.com/en/intro/

content.title: Everything about photography at the Centro Português de Fotografia

introduction.small: The history of photography unfolds before your eyes in this former prison, offering a free and truly original visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Everything about photography at the Centro Português de Fotografia

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Torre dos Clérigos district (Tower of Clerks), the Portuguese Centre of Photography has been promoting the national photographic heritage since 1997. Built in the 18th century, the structure that houses it today was formerly used as a Court of Appeal (Cadeia da Relação), and then as a prison from 1961 to 1974.
These past functions add to the singular atmosphere of the place. The high glass ceilings allow for the light to slide over the old stoned walls and bring an almost mythical dimension to this ancient human purgatory. Barred doors and windows could be movie material if you would let your imagination run wild.
Do not miss the permanent collection that sheds a light on the ancestors of our digital cameras: from daguerreotypes and folding cameras to modern reflex models and other disposable cameras or hidden spy ones. Works by trendy and contemporary photographers are on display in the temporary exhibition areas.

Centro Português de Fotografia (CPF)

content.title: Come experience alternative Porto at Passos Manuel

introduction.small: In the heart of the fantastic and modernist Coliseu, the Passos Manuel is here to tell the best stories of nighttime Porto. Inspiring dancing and drinking in a mutant vibe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Come experience alternative Porto at Passos Manuel

paragraphs.text:
The Coliseu (coliseum) was inaugurated in the winter of 1941, the stunning modernist building being the result of several architects, including José Port, Júlio de Brito and Cassiano Branco. Operas, ballet and music concerts used to take place in the 3000-seat arena. In 1971, the cine-studio Passos Manuel opened a more intimate venue with 300 seats dedicated to screening art films and independent programming.

The 2004 renovation is very 'Kubrick like', and while still involved in cinema, it has morphed into a bar, nightclub and concert hall. Located on the 4th floor of the Coliseu, the place is always full and is the gathering scene for alternative Porto from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. Two floors are meant for dancing and a sought-after bar alternates jazz, rock and electronic music. Check the eclectic schedule on their Facebook page for concerts, exhibitions and film festivals.

content.title: Reach your cruising speed!

introduction.small: Whether you want to visit Porto with a different viewpoint or push on to the Valley some 60 miles away, cruising the Douro is the promise of a romantic or family getaway.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Reach your cruising speed!

paragraphs.text:
Often called Portugal's River of Gold, the Douro is the perfect witness of the ongoing love story between man and vines, amidst blossoming mimosas. Cruise the river for an unusual sight over the city's sunny terraces and pink roofs. Porto will thus reveal an intimate and nostalgic image, filled with generations of wine growers working the land and building terraced walls along the shores.
Go with the flow for close to an hour on the famous Six Bridges river cruise, between Porto and Vila Nova de Gaia. You will get close and below the following bridges: Dom Luís I, Arrábida, Maria Pia, São João, Infante and Freixo. If you feel like it, take one or two extra days and go to Régua and Pinhão from the Porto landing stage. Finally, if you happen to have some more time ahead of you, why not try a six, seven - hell, even eight - day-cruise? You will sail along till Pocinho and Barca d'Alva, a small hamlet that is a good place to settle, near the International Douro Natural Park. Wander around the perfumed lines of green vines swaying softly along the curbs of the Douro Valley.

Turismo do Porto e Norte de Portugal

content.title: “Fado in Porto”, let the show begin!

introduction.small: Do you want a fado experience like no other? Then head over to one of the most famous wine cellars in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: “Fado in Porto”, let the show begin!

paragraphs.text:
The brand was founded in 1859 by António Alves Cálem. It now opens the doors of a historical cellar to visitors. Come and live an unusual and unforgettable experience amidst the Cálem cellars and enjoy a truly unique Fado in Porto show. While sipping on a glass of wine or not, you will discover the special features of this melancholic singing that reveals much about the Portuguese spirit.
Emblematic for wine and heritage enthusiasts, the Cálem wine cellars are among the most famous in the whole city, offering products of an incredible high-end quality. For the entire duration of the show, a selection of Cálem port wines will be served to properly accompany this magical moment. As hard as it may be, restrain from indulging too much on the beverage as you will assuredly want to enjoy the performance. Fado has been designated a UNESCO intangible cultural heritage and tells the story of a people and their culture.

content.title: Party time on the Rua da Galeria de Paris

introduction.small: In the midst of lively Porto, the Rua da Galeria de Paris is the first meeting point for those who want to have fun and party.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Party time on the Rua da Galeria de Paris

paragraphs.text:
Every night in the historical artery of the city, the Rua Galeria de Paris welcomes night owls looking to be entertained. Trendy bars and restaurants line up, offering a friendly and easy-going atmosphere. Outside on the pavement, the crowd sometimes stops to listen to musicians performing, dance and cross paths till the end of the night.
After a busy day, full of promenades and visits around town, come and relax with a drink in hand, or enjoy a short concert in one of the many venues offering artists a chance to perform. If you wish to have dinner, there is no shortage of fine addresses. We recommend the Galeria de Paris restaurant-café, which preserved the charms of the former fabrics shop that came before. Peaceful during the day, it becomes incredibly lively at night, favoured by many Portuenses looking to party. Great atmosphere guaranteed!

content.title: LSD, Porto's trendy HQ

introduction.small: In the modern Ribeira neighbourhood, among design stores and trendy places, the recently opened LSD restaurant is already quite a hit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LSD, Porto's trendy HQ

paragraphs.text:
Perfectly located at the bottom of the Rua das Flores, on a small praça where shade and sun fight it out, and a few steps away from the Douro, the LSD restaurant awaits you. Do not worry! There is no hallucinogenic on the menu, as the place is simply named after the Largo de São Domingos street. The restaurant offers a nice terrace where you can enjoy salads, sandwiches or pata negra during the day, and two modern and streamlined dining rooms inside. The LSD chef revisits Portuguese cuisine by including unusual ingredients such as cocoa, vanilla or sweet potatoes. On the menu you will find oven-cooked shoulder of milk-fed lamb, codfish salad with chickpea and orange, homemade duck ham, and even octopus with black rice, spinach and roasted tomatoes… Whatever you choose, there will be a perfect wine to come enhance the flavours, all to be enjoyed in a young and trendy atmosphere.

content.title: Livraria Lello, a world of books

introduction.small: With more than 60,000 titles on its shelves, this large and imposing bookshop is among Porto's most unusual spots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Livraria Lello, a world of books

paragraphs.text:
Stand in front of the entrance, raise your head and lay your eyes on the two figures that surround the large window opening: Art and Science welcome you here. Since 1906, this bookshop of undisputed decorative beauty has been considered a 'house of letters' by the many intellectuals and writers that Porto counts in its midst, browsing an incredible number of rare books. In spite of the years, this Neo-gothic architectural gem shelters a temple of literary culture in Porto (with more than 60,000 electronically indexed titles available) in pristine conditions. Book lovers, students and academics rub shoulders with tourists in front of the imposing central staircase, between old books of spells and wooden shelves. Due to the current craze surrounding the history of the place, staff are having to be extra careful to ensure the shop remains just that: a shop. This has led to the introduction of a 5 EUR entry fee, but bookworms should fear not: the fee is deductible from any book purchase made.
Treasure hunters, note that gems like the three volumes of Reynaldo dos Santos' Oito séculos de arte portuguesa, or the facsimile of Luís de Camões' Os Lusíadas'(1572) first edition sit jealously guarded in the owner's office! Finally, J.K. Rowling enthusiasts will gladly learn that the writer took her inspiration there for Hogwarts, Harry Potter's school.

content.title: Family stroll in town

introduction.small: Youngsters will never be bored in Porto. Delight your kids with surprising visits, promenades through parks and playful activities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Family stroll in town

paragraphs.text:
Porto's city centre is ideal to walk around with your family. On foot, the steep and narrow streets of the historical centre make it possible for the youngest ones not to grow weary too fast. Take this opportunity to photograph some beautiful azulejos, the beautiful blue tiles so typical of the Portuguese urban landscape.
If you suddenly feel tired, hop on one of the various yellow trams. Built in wood, they are being driven by courteous drivers who will give you the impression of travelling back in time. They can take you up to the beach if you crave for outdoor activities, or even to the Sea Life Porto aquarium, filled with marine creatures with strange names and stranger shapes.
A stone's throw away from the aquarium is the Parque da Cidade do Porto (City Park), where you should spend a couple of hours, on foot or by bike. If you would rather visit the city's other gardens, try the Palácio de Cristal, very suitable for endless games of hide and seek. As for the riverside, the Douro crosses over town and allows for hour-long boat trips that will delight the whole family.

content.title: Porto, a display of architecture and cultural heritage

introduction.small: Porto offers a dazzling display of old architecture. Be they Romanesque, Gothic, Baroque or Contemporary, the Portuguese city gathers them all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Porto, a display of architecture and cultural heritage

paragraphs.text:
Designated a UNESCO world heritage site, Porto offers an incredibly rich architectural heritage. The traditional azulejos that adorn numerous buildings give a singular charm to the city. About a hundred listed monuments are accessible in the historical centre. Amid the Ribeira, Batalha and Miragaia districts, churches especially are genuine testimonies of Portuenses' (inhabitants of Porto) Catholic fervour. On the other side of town on the south bank, the Serra do Pilar monastery is not-to-be-missed: it offers an incredible view onto the city, and the circular-shaped church is unique in all Portugal.
As for the bridges, they are an integral part of Porto's history. Six of them overhang the Douro banks. Dom Luís I is the most famous of them all, conceived by Théophile Seyrig, a student of Gustave Eiffel, when many tourists wrongly believe the latter to be the actual architect. Truth be told, it looks a lot like the Maria Pia bridge, drawn by the 'master' himself only half a mile away.
The work of Dutch 'star' Rem Koolhaas, the famous Casa da Música ('House of Music') shows a newer side of Porto. The city is changing and has definitely entered a new modern era.

content.title: Solar Quinta da Portela, an oasis lost in the valley

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Solar Quinta da Portela, an oasis lost in the valley

paragraphs.text:
The Douro region gets its name from the river that flows through it, the Douro. From the warm hues on the houses to green hills and vineyards as far as the eye can see, not counting churches perched atop hillsides, you will love this sunny and quiet area in the heart of Portugal. If you plan to stay for several days, spend one night at the Solar Quinta da Portela, an estate lost in the middle of vines. The building, with its bright Mediterranean yellow walls, immediately catches the eye of the curious traveller. This guesthouse is run by a Portuguese family whose life is paced by the visiting guests. Proud of their region, they welcome you with generosity and take time to share tips regarding your trip. Comfortable and charming rooms, a pool, a tennis court and an outdoor terrace for lunch add to the charm of this estate where life is sweet.

content.title: Time stands still at the Grande Hotel do Porto

introduction.small: A few minutes from the famous Art Deco Coliseu theatre and Porto Cathedral, the stone façade of the Grande Hotel do Porto is as charming as it is intriguing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Time stands still at the Grande Hotel do Porto

paragraphs.text:
Conveniently located on one of the main shopping streets of the city, the hotel exhibits both an elegant and old-world look. Mouldings, chandeliers and velvets from the large lobby will send you back in time. Impressive columns nearby stand in the lounge, while fiery vermeil and carmine bring warm luxury to the Windsor bar.
After a sports class and a massage, leave the classical common areas and enter a simple and refined room, providing full amenities: free Wi-Fi, flat screen TV, minibar and private bath with tub or shower. A few family rooms are available if you travel with kids. After a well-deserved break, walk a few steps down to the hotel most emblematic room. Set up in a particularly romantic restored ballroom, the Dom Pedro II restaurant offers authentic Portuguese cuisine prepared with local produce. Perfect for a stay out of time…

content.title: Six Senses, a chic refuge in the Douro valley

introduction.small: The Douro valley offers the perfect setting for a quiet retreat away from the bustle of civilization. Six Senses Douro is the perfect detox destination.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Six Senses, a chic refuge in the Douro valley

paragraphs.text:
A stunning region of breathtaking landscapes awaits you only an hour and a half from Porto. In this UNESCO world heritage site, vineyards expand endlessly in the Valley around exceptional estates, including the Six Senses Douro Valley.
This former farm was renovated into a place out of time: wherever you find yourself in the hotel, the views will take your breath away. This elegant and modern cocoon of 57 rooms will transport you to the heart of the valley's history. Come relax in the spa and enjoy Portuguese traditions and natural elements - stone, water and wood, an absolute must in terms of treatments.
As far as food is concerned, the chef will prepare a daily special, and since anything is possible here, you may pick vegetables in the hotel's vegetable garden and have the chef prepare them for you.

content.title: The legendary Quinta do Seixo terraced vineyards

introduction.small: Less than two hours from Porto by car, Quinta do Seixo is nestled in the Douro Valley, where the hundred grape varieties it produces are spread over a landscape offering spectacular vista.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The legendary Quinta do Seixo terraced vineyards

paragraphs.text:
The priceless Douro Valley lies at the heart of the Cima Corgo region. In its midst, Quinta do Seixo spreads over schist rock terraces (only 5 feet large) upon which only one vine stock is grown to allow for pesticide-free mechanical weeding. Note that the site has been designated a world heritage site by the UNESCO. More than a hundred purely Portuguese grape varieties grow there to produce port wine, Portugal's most famous drink.
Great Wine Centres such as Sandeman offer vineyard tours. Choose between the classic visit and tasting, to the uncommon picnic amongst the hundred-year old vines with the Douro at your feet. You will also be able to discover local food, cheese and other secret produce, and even visit the award-winning Vau Vintage winery. On your way back to Porto, make sure to stop by the Sandeman's historical wine cellars (built in 1790), which have a mysterious caped figure wearing a wide-brimmed hat as their logo...

content.title: The peaceful Foz do Douro district, by the sea

introduction.small: The waterfront awaits you only a 15-minute drive away from Porto. Welcome to the Foz district, facing the Atlantic Ocean!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The peaceful Foz do Douro district, by the sea

paragraphs.text:
The Portuguese bourgeoisie loves to bask in the sun on the waterfront, relax in the shade of palm trees, and entertain themselves in 19th-century or modern villas. It explains why residential and seaside Foz do Douro wins all the votes, away from the turmoil of the historical centre.
The Praia do Molhe is the famous beach around here and it runs alongside the Pérgola da Foz promenade, which remains cool in all circumstances due to the sea breeze. Completely lit up when night falls, the pier lends itself to solitary daydreaming and friendly card games. And with a boat trip around the Gulf of Porto, fishing, canoeing and paddling or lazing about on the shore, activities are not lacking in the least bit!
From the Praia de Gondarém beach, the more active travellers can reach the Castelo de Queijo or further south stop at the Jardim do Passeio Alegre, embellished by a lovely fountain. Finally, it is recommended to spend some time around the old São Miguel-o-Anjo lighthouse or the São João Baptista fort in Vila do Conde. You shall not be disappointed.

content.title: The Yeatman, looking out at the city

introduction.small: Regulars will tell you that The Yeatman Hotel has the best view of Porto, taking you right to the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yeatman, looking out at the city

paragraphs.text:
The Yeatman sits on the other side of the Douro, in the heart of the great winery neighbourhood of Porto, perched atop the heights of Vila Nova de Gaia. It is said that the restaurant houses the most extensive Portuguese wine collection in the world.
The design takes its cue from nearby cellars. Each of the 70 rooms and suites was customized by a partner winery to include its history and personality thanks to pictures, objects and wine bottles. Pick a room with a city view preferably. From the bay window the show is stunning at dusk.
At the hotel's Michelin-starred restaurant, chef Ricardo Costa serves an oenogastronomic menu based on seasons, twisting the traditional Portuguese cuisine with a modern flare. For the spa, The Yeatman chose Caudalie, the wine therapy expert. You may also enjoy a unique wellness centre with panoramic view of the city.

content.title: Tasty stroll in Porto

introduction.small: 'Porto works and Braga prays; Coimbra studies, but Lisbon plays!' is an old saying. It is true, Porto has been working hard: its reputation as a food city is flourishing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tasty stroll in Porto

paragraphs.text:
Porto is often lovingly described as hard-working by its inhabitants. The city bottles the most delicious wines and offers the most typical food. Since 2000, Portologia has opened the doors of its perfumed cellars to the best grape varieties of the season, while Socalcos Vinhos & Gourmet invites you to roam through rows of wondrous bottles.
If you like coffee with chocolate or floral notes, head over to the historical Guarany café-restaurant. You cannot leave Porto without trying the famous francesinha (the little French one), made of white bread slices coated in gruyere cheese, and filled with a beef steak, cooked ham, a sausage and mortadella. Covered with an egg, grilled and drenched in a delicious hot sauce, it will assuredly delight your taste-buds. This food stroll will end in an abundance of fresh fruit and vegetables at the Bolhão market, a symbol of what Porto has to offer.

content.title: Vinum, the prominent spot we were waiting for

introduction.small: The Vinum restaurant is located in the heart of Graham's cellar and offers a unique gastronomic experience - between design and heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vinum, the prominent spot we were waiting for

paragraphs.text:
On the left bank of the river, by Vila Nova de Gaia, Vinum offers one of the best panoramic views of Porto. Come and make yourself comfortable, as you enjoy the view. Day and night, you can look down at historical downtown, a UNESCO designated world heritage site, as well as at the Douro and famous Dom Luís I bridge. A unique experience.
3,000 barrels are piled up all around you. Graham's has maintained the original decoration, walls, pine beams and cast-iron pillars from the 19th century. The large bay windows, granite walls and dancing lights add a very modern feel to the place. In the kitchen, all the dishes are matched with port wine, some of the best in the world. Taste the codfish in broad beans, green peas and citrus fruit - the day's catch comes from the Matosinhos' covered market - or duck fillets with roasted apples and foie gras. The view is gorgeous, the meal a delight and the wines a treat. Get a glimpse of the sweet life in Porto.

Vinum Restaurant & Wine Bar
Rua do Agro 141

+351 22 093 0417

www.vinumatgrahams.com/en/

Menu: about 37 EUR

content.title: Window shopping in the historical centre

introduction.small: From traditional shops to upcoming designer outlets and international brands, shopping addicts will find what they are looking for.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Window shopping in the historical centre

paragraphs.text:
Why not start your shopping spree with a key spot in Porto? Santa Catarina street is located in a car-free area of the city centre and considered to be the main shopping artery. You will find common international ready-to-wear brands rubbing shoulders with craft outlets and small jewellery shops.

On Rua de Mouzinho da Silveira, you can purchase some colourful sardine, tuna and octopus cans at Loja das Conservas. Near the Rua do Almada and Rua da Fábrica, famous for its bookshops, enter Almada 13, a very eclectic concept store. On that same street, you will taste delicious treats at Arcádia, a traditional chocolate maker renowned for its large selection and chocolate-covered finger biscuits.

Further west, head straight to CRU, a dynamic concept store that houses showrooms, workshops and fashion boutiques to help shed a light on new and upcoming designers. In the same neighbourhood, you will meander your way through Rua Miguel Bombarda (you can also visit its mall), which gathers numerous contemporary art galleries in its midst, some of which have the best Portuguese artists on display.

Not far from there in the Ribeira district and near the Douro River, you will come across mercearias, grocery shops specialised in Portuguese products (cheeses, olive oil, cold cuts and wine). Rua das Flores was a former jewellery goldsmithery trade street and a few shops selling handcrafted jewellery remain. There is no better location to laze about, stride across the paved streets and feel the city's atmosphere.

content.title: Winemaking at Quinta da Pacheca

introduction.small: The Quinta da Pacheca is a gorgeous vineyard in the Douro Valley. It offers you a unique experience: make your own wine according to ancient traditions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Winemaking at Quinta da Pacheca

paragraphs.text:
'Pacheca'. About 120 km from Porto, the name of the estate stands proudly on Quinta da Pacheca's wrought iron gate. It comes from the Pacheco family, who owned the land in the 1700s. Three centuries later, port wine is still being produced. From generation to generation, wine has consistently been made using unique craft and savoir-faire, which you will learn about during the two months of grape harvest.
For a few days, the estate offers you to live the life of a winegrower of yesteryears. Pick up bunches of grapes, stomp them while singing folk songs and cask the wine to start the ageing process. At the end of your stay, you will know everything about the various port and regular wines of the Douro Valley. Tastings are planned on each session, during which aromas and flavours of each drink are being explained.

content.title: Romantic stay at the Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel

introduction.small: Your journey through the “undefeated city” reaches its pinnacle at the Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel, a charming place established in 1829 on the banks of the peaceful Douro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Romantic stay at the Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel

paragraphs.text:
The Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel is located between Avenida dos Aliados and the medieval alleys in Ribeira. The Araújo e Sobrinho historical building, one of Portugal's most important and Europe's oldest paper mill, was turned into a splendid modern hotel with bluish façade and rod iron balconies.
The hotel offers 41 elegant and refined rooms, some with spotless claw foot tubs. Others are equipped with private bath and panoramic view onto the colourful splendours of the city.
Your every need will be met: AC, flat TV screens, free Wi-Fi, room service breakfast available upon request as well as Portuguese snacks. The Galeria do Largo restaurant does justice to the country's culinary reputation: chef Manuel Ferreira now offers typically local delights right where artists used to show their works.

With this prime location, the Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel is an ideal starting point for exploring the city's many secrets, whether as a couple, a family or among friends.

Porto A.S. 1829 Hotel
Largo de São Domingos 45-55
4050-097 Porto

+351 22 340 2740

https://as1829.luxhotels.pt/

Rooms: from 114 EUR

content.title: Vícios de Mesa, work yourself up into a… pizza

introduction.small: After enjoying an exhibition at the Maus Hábitos, one of Porto's hippest cultural centres, take a seat at the 4th-floor pizzeria.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vícios de Mesa, work yourself up into a… pizza

paragraphs.text:
The building may look a bit old and passé, but make no mistake: this 1950s looking car garage hides a modern cultural centre. Here you will find modern design and programming of concerts, exhibitions and high-end installations. Wander around this magical place and discover room after room of artistic wonders.
Once you have gone around, go up to the Vícios de Mesa, a pizzeria offering vegetarian options tucked away on the 4th floor. Delicious pizzas and - added bonus - a city view! Pay homage to a star and try the Madonna pizza: with spinach, caramelised onions, black olives and rocket, it is every bit as stunning as one of her songs. Save a little room for homemade desserts. After your meal, enjoy a nightcap on the outdoor terrace serving perfect cocktails. They are extremely popular, especially the caipirinha!

Vícios de Mesa
Rue Passos Manuel 178
4000-382 Porto

+351 93 720 2918

https://www.maushabitos.com/menu/

Menu: around 14 EUR

content.title: PortoBay Hotel Teatro, magical location in an ancient theatre

introduction.small: Right in the heart of Porto's historical district, the PortoBay Hotel Teatro is the city's first International Design Hotel labelled address.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: PortoBay Hotel Teatro, magical location in an ancient theatre

paragraphs.text:
The PortoBay Teatro Hotel was established where the famous Baquet Theatre once stood: the original building was designed by António Pereira Baquet in 1859, but burned down in 1888. Now though, the hotel pays homage to this fabulous venue, recreating the sophisticated yet bohemian atmosphere that made the theatre so special.
Enjoy the large foyer, warmed by tawny ceilings and gold and bronze furniture. Spread out over six floors, the hotel's 74 rooms offer elegant bathrooms and top of the art installations. Away from the city's bustle, come spend time in a bright courtyard, a high-tech gym, the Palco restaurant, or Plateia bar. Of course, the hotel offers all sorts of amenities, from the simplest to the most sophisticated: free Wi-Fi, parking available upon request, laundry as well as meeting and special events facilities.

PortoBay Hotel Teatro
Rua Sá da Bandeira 84
4000-427 Porto

+351 22 040 9620

https://www.portobay.com/en/hotels/porto-hotels/portobay-hotel-teatro/

Rooms: from 134 EUR

content.title: In search of Taylor's wine cellars

introduction.small: Cross the Douro and visit Vila Nova de Gaia and the famous Taylor's wine cellars!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In search of Taylor's wine cellars

paragraphs.text:
Taylor's wine cellars are probably one of the best places in town to learn about port wine's history. The three-century-old venerable institution is quite simply among the oldest in the entire region.
The premises were renovated to offer curious travellers some playful, interactive and customized visits. Upon arrival, a map of the region will help you better grasp Porto's geographic situation, as well as the surroundings. It will then be time to visit the cellars themselves, casks and tuns aligned to let the wines mature. You will move on to a gallery devoted to vines and grape varieties before watching a short presentation in the screening room. After that discovery of Taylor's history, it will be time for the apex of the visit: the wine tasting. Three different port wines will tickle your taste buds: a white port, a tawny and a vintage... Just remember to drink responsibly. Just outside the winery, the Barão Fladgate restaurant offers wine-food pairing for either lunch or dinner.

Taylor's Port
Rua do Choupelo 250
4400-088 Vila Nova de Gaia

+351 22 374 2800

https://www.taylor.pt/

content.title: M – Maison Particulière, family charm of a landmark

introduction.small: In the heart of Porto, this charming hotel displays the refinement of Portuguese townhouses and authenticity of family homes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: M – Maison Particulière, family charm of a landmark

paragraphs.text:
Located in the city's old town, this UNESCO world heritage site is special for multiple reasons. This 16th-century building is a unique place where walls can attest to great moments in the city's history. Upon visiting the house, Marco Leite de Faria and his mother, Maria Irene Schultze, immediately fell in love with this run-down treasure. They felt these vestiges held tremendous potential.
After a few months, their love for old stones and a certain way of life led to the rebirth of a sublime abode. Just like they did, come fall in love with the figurative original azulejos on the high walls leading to the terrace. The ten rooms are decorated in a timeless style with antique furniture, high ceilings, stucco and murals. It is as if you were entering your own pied-à-terre. At M - Maison Particulière you will feel particularly at home.

M - Maison Particulière
Largo de São Domingos 66
4050-545 Porto

+351 22 766 1400

www.m-porto.com

Rooms: from 235 EUR

content.title: Os Lusíadas, gills on fire!

introduction.small: Follow in the footsteps of Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama who discovered the sea route to India in 1498.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Os Lusíadas, gills on fire!

paragraphs.text:
In a port city on the outskirts of Porto, the Os Lusíadas restaurant lovingly cares for its fish and seafood. The restaurant is in Matosinhos, home to the country's largest fishing port, Leixões. Thanks to a strong local fishing industry, the restaurant is proud to prepare its seafood in absolute freshness.
Fish eggs in Algarve sauce, seabass, sole, grouper, codfish and many others... Enjoy the waltz of waiters carrying these dishes in a light and simple decor. Pair these precious and incredibly delicate dishes with one of the many wines on the list and indulge in a blind tasting inspired by sea aromas. For the record, the restaurant was named after the Lusiades (Os Lusíadas), the epic poem by the great 16th century Portuguese poet Luís Vaz de Camões, or “Camoens”, that recounts the epic journeys of Vasco de Gama: a classic of Lusitanian literature.

Os Lusíadas
Rua de Tomaz Ribeiro 257
4450-297 Matosinhos

+351 22 937 8242

https://restaurantelusiadas.com/en/os-lusiadas/

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: NH Collection Porto Batalha, in the heart of a palace

introduction.small: Setting up hotels in superb historical buildings has been a trend in Porto for a few years, combining elegance and culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: NH Collection Porto Batalha, in the heart of a palace

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Porto's 'Golden Triangle' (between the São Bento station, the Stock Exchange Palace and the Dom Luís I bridge), only a few steps away from the shopping district, the NH Collection Porto Batalha is the perfect starting point for a stroll through the historical centre. Former home to a rich family of wine growers, this 18th-century palace was entirely renovated back to its former lustre.
As you face the sumptuous red building, walk through the doors and into the lobby and feel the warm and thoughtful welcome. Climb the stairs to one of the 107 rooms - all very modern. A piece of advice: pick the 4th floor, where the rooms have small terraces overlooking Porto with a view of the Batalha square and Teatro Nacional São João, an architectural gem. On the kitchen side, chef Paulo Leite offers a wide menu, including one of the best burgers in town. At last, you can relax at the wellness centre or do some cardio on the machines… but there is no obligation!

NH Collection Porto Batalha
Praça da Batalha 60-65
4000-101 Porto

+351 22 766 0600

https://www.nh-collection.com/en/hotel/nh-collection-porto-batalha

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: Rib Beef and Wine, meat summa cum laude

introduction.small: Small oddity on Porto's gastronomic scene, Rib Beef & Wine is a steakhouse that serves carefully picked meat dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rib Beef and Wine, meat summa cum laude

paragraphs.text:
By the Douro, in the Ribeira neighbourhood, the Pestana Vintage Porto hotel restaurant has chosen to stand out. The Rib Beef & Wine is the only place in town offering 'protected designation of origin' meat dishes with rich sauces, quite different from the culinary traditions usually found in Porto. On the menu, you will find the "traditional" beef cut with coriander, eggs, meat croquetes and onion sauce, or beef cheeks with a potato mousseline. What matters most is the cut and the cooking of the meat, thought out to pay tribute to the quality of the product in itself.

You can choose among various sides - beans, rice or turnip green compote - and of course tomato and candied onions, as well as port wine served with every dish. Vegetarians, fear not, the restaurant also offers 'cool alternatives': salads and vegetables in vinegar, tomato soup and soft-boiled egg…

Rib Beef & Wine
Pestana Vintage Porto Hotel
Praça da Ribeira 1
4050-513 Porto

+351 96 627 3822

https://www.rib.pt/index-en

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: A voyage into the heart of the Fundação de Serralves

introduction.small: Make the most of an artistic circuit in one of the largest multicultural centres of Northern Portugal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A voyage into the heart of the Fundação de Serralves

paragraphs.text:
Located close to the Avenida da Boavista, one of Porto's main roads, the Serralves Foundation was built amidst a lovely 18-hectare park. Start the circuit by visiting the famous Modern Art Museum, opened in 1999 and designed by Portuguese architect Alvaro Siza. The museum was first thought out as part of an ensemble to make Porto a European capital of culture, which so happened in 2001. Nowadays, it shelters permanent collections of major works of art, of all styles and movements from the past decades. Moviegoers will enjoy a detour by the House of Cinema, a structure entirely dedicated to the work of Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira.
Prolong the visit and stroll around the park of the foundation, showcasing lush gardens and miniature ponds. Enjoy those moments of peace and quiet before heading to the Casa de Serralves, headquarters of the foundation. Built in an Art Deco style, it offers plenty of avant-garde temporary exhibitions.

Fundação de Serralves
Rua Dom João de Castro 210
4150-417 Porto

+351 22 615 6500

https://www.serralves.pt/en/

content.title: Cantinho do Avillez: keep it a secret!

introduction.small: This small restaurant, well known to locals, serves Portuguese cuisine with a twist.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cantinho do Avillez: keep it a secret!

paragraphs.text:
Perched high up on the Rua Mouzinho da Silveira, this is an address that connoisseurs share, a place where you will find many regulars and well-informed visitors for lunch. Chef José Avillez now runs this restaurant, after extensive experiences at Le Bristol Paris and the three-Michelin-star El Bulli in Catalonia before it closed down in 2011.
After his many apprenticeships, José Avillez settled in Lisbon where he served Portuguese cuisine nicely imprinted with his travels. Today he shares his experience at Cantinho do Avillez in Porto. On the menu: scallops in a creamy avocado sauce with a Pão alentejano sourdough crumb, the famous francesinha - a typical dish made with linguiça (fresh sausage, ham and beef) - or scallops with portobello mushroom risotto. For something sweet, try the local speciality of 'toucinho do céu' (‘bacon from heaven'), a type of custard tart served with raspberry sorbet.

Cantinho do Avillez
Rua Mouzinho da Silveira 166
4050-416 Porto

+351 22 322 7879

https://www.cantinhodoavillez.pt/en/restaurantes/mouzinho-da-silveira.html

Menu: around 21 EUR

content.title: Majestic Café, like the Belle Époque

introduction.small: Every city fondly maintains a brasserie, complete with its original style and unique atmosphere. In Porto, head to Majestic Café for an immersion into the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Majestic Café, like the Belle Époque

paragraphs.text:
The marble façade has not changed and since 1921, the Porto intelligentsia has been meeting up for coffee at the Majestic. Today, it is so successful that you may have to get in line at rush hour to get in. This art deco gem may have become a tourist spot, but local customers still come, faithful to the historical lounges and Belle Époque mirrors.
Art nouveau lovers will recognize the leather seats, typical chandeliers and beautifully painted ceiling lamps. Once you are seated, order coffee with a delicious pastel de nata, small custard filling a flaky pastry. Enjoy this divine moment. For a few minutes, the brouhaha will fade, you will be transported to the1920s, a time when writers would come here and talk or meditate for hours. Who knows, you might get inspired…

Majestic Café
Rua Santa Catarina 112
4000-442 Porto

+351 22 200 3887

https://www.cafemajestic.com/en/Utilities/Homepage.aspx

Coffee: 5 EUR

Pastel de nata: 3 EUR

content.title: Casa da Música, all for music!

introduction.small: The Casa da Música was designed by Dutch architect and Pritzker award winner Rem Koolhaas as a structure devoted entirely to music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa da Música, all for music!

paragraphs.text:
The inception of the project goes back to 1999, when Porto was about to become the European Capital of Culture (in 2001). Today, Casa da Música clashes with the rest of the city's more traditional architecture. Located only a few minutes from the historical centre in the Boavista district, this “House of Music” quickly became a symbol of the modern side of Porto.
To discover this concrete, aluminium and glass construct, visits are organised all year long. First devised as a small villa, Rem Koolhaas' project morphed into a unique cultural centre of nearly 38,000 sqm. A captivating guide will tell you about the building's singular architecture and the various forms of music as well. Symphony concerts, jazz gigs and clubbing nights all coexist here. And if you are a little bit hungry, Casa da Música houses an excellent restaurant, open for lunch and dinner. Of course, you will also be able to listen to some music there.

Casa da Música
Avenida da Boavista 604-610
4149-071 Porto

+351 22 012 0220

www.casadamusica.com/en/#

content.title: Euskalduna Studio, a culinary experience

introduction.small: Dive into the culinary world of chef Vasco Coelho and discover his new concepts and experiments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Euskalduna Studio, a culinary experience

paragraphs.text:
Euskalduna means 'the Basque' in Basque language. Chef Vasco Coelho Santos named his newest Porto project as a tribute to his roots. After a long experience in Basque country and Catalonia, he chose to set up a 'private kitchen' where special attention was placed on produce. After two long years of testing, he perfected his culinary skills and decided to create a new space exclusively dedicated to welcoming his guests: Euskalduna Studio.
In this intimate and sophisticated atmosphere, come and sit at the green marble bar or at one the welcoming oak tables. The tasting menu is articulated around ten dishes, which are divided into several appetizers, main courses and desserts. The dishes change regularly based on the seasonal offerings and market finds. As far as wines are concerned, the sommelier will be more than happy to match the wines and the dishes. Just divine!

Euskalduna Studio
Rua de Santo Ildefonso 404
4000-466 Porto

+351 93 533 5301

www.euskaldunastudio.pt

Menu: around 105 EUR

content.title: Estádio do Dragão, to enjoy a football game

introduction.small: You will find all the city's portistas - FC Porto supporters - gathered at the Estádio do Dragão.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Estádio do Dragão, to enjoy a football game

paragraphs.text:
On the edge of town, this architectural monument is home to the Futebol Clube do Porto, a.k.a. FC Porto. The city emblem plays the premier league and won the national championship no less than 15 times! Portuenses are known to be portistas, faithful supporters of their team. Should you need proof of the assertion, you need to realise that the stadium may welcome up to 50,000 people, almost a quarter of the city's population!
If you happen to love football and crave for a game, just go for the extraordinary atmosphere that prevails in the Estádio do Dragão, christened after the players' 'dragons' nickname. Moreover, the building was awarded the 'Greenlight' European certificate, for parsimonious use of energy sources and lighting on the premises. On your way out, keep an eye out for you may cross paths with some of Portugal's greatest football players.

Dragons Stadium (Estádio do Dragão)
Via Futebol Clube do Porto
4350-415 Porto

+351 22 507 0500

https://www.fcporto.pt/en/club/estadio-do-dragao/

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Porto
content.introduction:
Porto enjoys a Mediterranean climate with an oceanic influence.
Rain is quite abundant, temperatures are mild in winter, and summers are pleasantly warm and sunny.

airports.title: Porto-Francisco Sá-Carneiro International Airport
airports.description:
The Porto-Francisco Sá-Carneiro airport is located approximately 11 kilometres (6.2 miles) northwest from the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Porto and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via highway 107 and the IC 24. Travel time is around 15 minutes.
    • 5 parking facilities are available:
      - P0: EUR 1,10 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 1 per extra 15 minutes (EUR 24 25 for 24 hours).
      - P1: EUR 0.95 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 0.85 per extra 15 minutes (EUR 14 for 24 hours).
      - P4: EUR 0.75 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 0.70 per extra 15 minutes (EUR 10.50 for 24 hours).
      - P6: EUR 0.60 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 0.60 per extra 15 minutes (EUR 8 for 24 hours). - P9: EUR 0.55 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 0.55 per extra 15 minutes (EUR 7.50 for 24 hours).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall (ground level).
  • By metro
    • Line E of the Metro (the purple line) connects the airport to the city every 20 to 30 minutes from 6 a.m. to 1:30 a.m. Travel time is about 30 minutes, and a single ticket costs EUR 2. For further information, please visit https://en.metrodoporto.pt
  • By bus
    • Lines 601, 602 and 604 run between the airport and the city centre from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. One single ticket costs EUR 2.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the arrivals hall. Vehicles are equipped with a meter. Average fares to the centre of Porto around EUR 15 (EUR 0.74 per kilometre, plus service charge). Expect 20% increase during weekends and public holidays, and also an extra charge for heavy luggage. For further information, please visit www.antral.pt
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +351 22 943 2400
  • Website: https://www.aeroportoporto.pt/en/opo/home

transportation.description: Porto has an efficient public transport system. In addition, the underground trains, trams, buses and funiculars all have the advantage of being relatively inexpensive. Of course, the best way to discover the city is by foot.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Portuguese phrases that will make your stay in Porto a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Bom dia (morning) / Boa tarde (afternoon)
What time is it?: Que horas são ?
Where can I find (…)?: Onde é que há (…)?
Where can I buy (…)?: Onde posso comprar (…)?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Porto
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Porto each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: The week leading to Easter: Holy Week (Semana santa) (national holiday)
events.description: Holy Week takes place one week before Easter and is celebrated with religious events around the country, including several in Porto. A sizeable crowd always gathers in the streets to pray, or admire the impressive procession of penitents as they move along to the music.

events.title: April 25: Liberty Day (Dia da Liberdade) (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the Carnation Revolution on this day in 1974 that brought an end to the dictatorship of António de Oliveira Salazar and restored democracy in Portugal. Festivities include live music and dancing in the streets.

events.title: June 10: National Day (Dia de Camões) (national holiday)
events.description: Celebrated as Portugal's national day, this holiday also commemorates the death, on June 10, 1580, of the country's most famous poet, Luis de Camões. A huge fireworks display is launched over the Douro River.

events.title: June 23-24: Sao Joao holiday (São João) (local holiday)
events.description: Porto is probably the city that celebrates São João with most pomp. Numerous concerts take place all over town and masses gather in the streets, and restaurants are crowded. On that day, tradition asks that sardines be prepared as a dish, and people joyfully hit each other with soft plastic hammers.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (Assunção da Virgem Maria) (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, processions celebrate the Assumption of the Virgin Mary. Masses and processions take place in the churches and all over the historic centre of Porto.

events.title: October 5: Republic Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the overthrow of Portugal's constitutional monarchy by republican forces on this day in 1910 and the founding of the first Portuguese republic. A ceremony is held outside Porto's city hall with officials and politicians.

events.title: December 1: Independence Day (Dia da Independência) (national holiday)
events.description: This day commemorates the restoration of Portuguese independence from Spain in 1640 and is celebrated in the streets of the city with various festivities, including parades, meals and concerts.

events.title: December 31 : New Year's Eve (national holiday)
events.description: Street parties, concerts and fireworks displays are organized all over the city, particularly in the Ribeira neighbourhood.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Portugal
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Portugal for less than three months. However, your national identity card or passport must be valid for the duration of your stay.
To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Porto and Portugal, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations.

Comprehensive information that may be helpful is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/portugal/

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Porto like everywhere in Portugal, tips are particularly appreciated. Waiting staff have demanding jobs and good service should be rewarded. There is no hard-and-fast rule for the percentage. Leave whatever amount you feel is appropriate.
